facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 252 of 1954 filed as appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 22nd January 1953 of Election Tribunal Vellore in Election Petition No. 35 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd January 1953 of the Election Tribunal, Vellore in Election Petition No. 35 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SINHA J on March 29, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. March 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA. J.-The only question for determination in this appeal

facts.text: Facts of the case not in dispute and lie within narrow compass.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of this case are number in dispute and lie within a narrow companypass.

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 3 contested last general elections from Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency in Salem district, Madras State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondents I to 3 companytested the last general elections from the Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency in the district of Salem in the State of Madras.

facts.text: Respondents 4 to 10 were candidates, nominations valid, withdrew before polling.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 4 to 10 who were added subsequently by an order of the Tribunal were also candidates for election. Their numberinations also had been held to be valid but they ultimately withdrew their candidature before the polling took place.

facts.text: Appellant declared elected to the House of the People.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was in due companyrse declared to have been elected to the House of the People.

facts.text: 1st respondent filed election petition on 5th March 1952 contesting appellant's election on ground of disqualification under section 7(d) of Representation of the People Act 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on the 5th March, 1952 the 1st respondent filed an election petition before the Election Commission companytesting the appellants election on the ground that the appellant was disqualified under section 7 d  of the Act

facts.text: Appellant holds stage carriage service permit Ex. B-2 dated 26th April 1949 issued by Regional Transport Authority, Salem, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage it is necessary to state that it is admitted that the appellant is and has been the holder of a stage carriage service permit  Ex. B-2  dated the 26th April 1949, issued by the Regional Transport Authority, Salem, Madras.

facts.text: Permit condition: if called upon, appellant to enter agreement with Government of India for transport of postal articles and mail bags.

anchor.surface_text: It was one of the companyditions of the said permit that if called upon the appellant will enter into an agreement with the Government of India for the transport of postal articles and mail bags.

facts.text: Appellant entered registered agreement Ex. A-3 with Government of India on 16th November 1949 for transport of postal mail.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that obligation the appellant entered into a registered agreement with the Government of India on the 16th November 1949  Ex. A-3  to be numbericed in detail hereinafter.

facts.text: 1st respondent objected to appellant's nomination on 28th November 1951 on ground of contract with GoI for mail transport.

anchor.surface_text: After the appellant had filed his numberination paper, the 1st respondent by his petition dated the 28th November 1951 raised the objection to the effect that his numberination should be rejected on the ground that he had entered into a companytract with the Government of India

facts.text: Returning Officer overruled objection by order Ex. A-2 dated 28th November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer for the Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency, Salem, by his orders  Ex. A-2  of the same date overruled the objection holding that the service rendered by the appellant of carrying mail

facts.text: Appellant filed written statement on 28th May 1952 denying disqualification under section 7(d).

anchor.surface_text: To the election petition filed by the 1st respondent the appellant filed his written statement on the 28th May 1952 denying that he was disqualified for election as a member of Parliament

facts.text: Election Tribunal held appellant disqualified under section 7(d) by orders dated 20th January 1953.

anchor.surface_text: whether the appellant is disqualified-under section 7 d  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter called the Act  for election to the House of the People, as held by the Election Tribunal, North Arcot, Vellore, by its orders dated the 20th January, 1953

facts.text: Tribunal allowed election petition, declared appellant's election void under section 100(1)(c) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly it allowed the election petition and held the appellants election to be void in terms of section 100 1  c  of the Act, with companyts to the respondent. Hence this appeal.

issues.text: whether the appellant is disqualified under section 7(d) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 for election to the House of the People

anchor.surface_text: The only question for determination in this appeal by special leave is whether the appellant is disqualified-under section 7 d  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter called the Act

issues.text: Is the nomination of the 1st respt. invalid because of the prohibition contained in section 7(d) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, or for any of the reasons set forth in paras. 9 to 11 of the petition?

anchor.surface_text: On those pleadings the following issues were framed by the Election Tribunal- Is the nomination of the 1st respt. invalid because of the prohibition contained in section 7 d  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951,

issues.text: Has this Tribunal jurisdiction to decide the question as regards the disqualification of the returned candidate, because of article 103 of the Constitution of India?

anchor.surface_text: ? Has this Tribunal jurisdiction to decide the question as regards the disqualification of the returned candidate, because of article 103 of the Constitution of India? It is not necessary to refer to the additional issue

arguments.claim: Appellant not disqualified under section 7(d); carrying mails is normal government function statutorily reserved, not performance of any service undertaken by Government

anchor.surface_text: His contention was that it is the exclusive privilege of the Government of India to convey all postal articles from one place to another and it is a normal function of the Government statutorily reserved to itself. There is no justification to regard the carrying of mails from one place to another as the performance of any service undertaken by the Government.

arguments.court_reasoning: Postal service is undertaken by govt as welfare service, not mere sovereign function; contract creates interest

arguments.claim: Appellant carrying out obligations imposed by Rule 160-B of Madras Motor Vehicles Rules; no interest in contract for service under section 7(d)

anchor.surface_text: There is no justification to regard the carrying of mails from one place to another as the performance of any service undertaken by the Government. It was further averred on behalf of the appellant that it was not justifiable to regard him as having any interest in a contract for the performance of any service undertaken by the appropriate Government within the mischief of section 7 d  of the Act and that he had been only carrying out the obligations imposed upon him by Rule 160-B of the rules framed under the Motor Vehicles Act.

arguments.claim: Agreement not mere pre-existing statutory obligation; independent contract with special terms

anchor.surface_text: If he wished to steer clear of the difficulty created by section 7 of the Act, he could have given due notice to Government under clause 18 of the contract referred to above. On the expiry of the term of the notice he would have been free to stand for election to a State or Central Legislature.

holdings.text: The agreement Ex. A-3 is an independent contract, not merely a pre-existing statutory obligation under Rule 160-B Madras Motor Vehicles Rules

anchor.surface_text: But it was argued that the agreement was in pursuance of a pre-existing obligation imposed by the rule aforesaid framed under the Motor Vehicles Act. It is true that the permit does companytain a companydition that the permit-holder may be called upon to undertake transport of mail bags and postal articles but that is only a numberice to intending applicants

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permit condition is notice of possible call; actual agreement has own terms (e.g., termination notice, specific obligations); entered voluntarily after consultation on rates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative purpose requires legislators free from private interests in govt service contracts; appellant could have terminated via notice.

holdings.text: The appellant had a share or interest in a contract for the performance of services undertaken by the appropriate Government

anchor.surface_text: The material portion of the section is in these terms- A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of either House of Parlia- ment  b if, whether by himself or by any person or body of persons in trust for him or for his benefit or on his account, he has any share or interest in a companytract for the performance of any services undertaken by the appropriate Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly concerned for own benefit in mail transport contract; remunerated Rs.200/month; ongoing at nomination.

holdings.text: The present case is a straightforward illustration of the kind of contract contemplated by section 7(d) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: But it is clear, by a reference to the terms of the rule quoted above, that the amount of the remuneration had to be fixed by the department after companysultation with the carrier. It was always open to the latter to demur to the terms proposed by the department and if he found that the department was number prepared to accept his terms he was number bound to enter into the agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts fit s.7(d) precisely: govt service contract with interest; appellant chose to continue despite knowledge.
